channel.title: Kinematics on Foldable Robotics
channel.description: Recent content in Kinematics on Foldable Robotics

item.title: Graphical Synthesis
item.description: A popular way of deriving the desired kinematics of a device graphically has also been employed for centures.

item.title: Jacobians
item.description: A Jacobian is a matrix that collects the partial derivatives of rates of change between two vectors.

item.title: Kinematics Introduction
item.description: Prototyping in Paper A second step is to ideate, mock-up, and prototype candidate mechanisms in paper.

item.title: Singularities and Solver Problems
item.description: Many of the devices you will prototype are highly nonlinear mechanisms which may have certain charactersitics which are hard to solve for in your typical CAD sketcher.

item.title: Sketching 2D Kinematics in CAD
item.description: Introduction Steps Create a planar sketch Turn off the background color in Solidworks by changing the background to plain white in the options at the top of the viewport window.

item.title: Solidworks Export Tutorial
item.description: Introduction This tutorial picks up from the Solidworks Kinematics Tutorial

item.title: Solidworks Kinematics Tutorial
item.description: Solidworks is an attractive way to model popup devices because you can interact with the three-dimensional kinematics of your popup device.

item.title: Solve Triangle
item.description: This example shows how to solve geometric constraints for a triangle of given length sides

item.title: Solving Kinematics Numerically with Python
item.description:
Introduction

This module takes you through solving the motion of a device by using a numerical nonlinear solver to solve a complex system of constraint equations. We will be using a number of Python packages to do this.

item.title: Solving Nonlinear Four-Bar Constraints
item.description: Turn on inline plotting %matplotlib inline import required packages import pynamics from pynamics.

item.title: Symbolic Constraint Equations with Pynamics
item.description: Import libraries import pynamics from pynamics.system import System from pynamics.frame import Frame from pynamics.

item.title: Vector Constraint Equations
item.description: v,w perpendicular Here the intuition is that perpendicular lines have an angle of $\theta$ between them.

item.title: Vectors and Vector Math
item.description: A $\vec{v}$ defines a magnitude and direction in $n$-dimensional space.
